creation.title: Creation of the Virtual Machine
creation.step1: Start Tesseract, and click on Create a new Virtual Machine
creation.step3: Under Installation Media, you will be presented with two options:
creation.step3-1-tip: After clicking on the download button, your browser will open and the download will start. Wait for it to finish before continuing!
creation.step3-2: If you already have one or you just downloaded from the previous step, click on + Pick a file to open the Finder file picker
creation.step5-tip: This settings affects execution speed and other factors. Leave it on Balanced if you are not sure!
creation.step6: Select the optional features to enable for your virtual machine
creation.step6-info:
Network type: This option let's you decide wether the virtual machine should be network isolated (None), connected using NAT (Shared) or on a bridged network (Advanced). Shared is recommended for beginner users.
Enable shared directory: this option creates for you a folder that is shared between your mac and your Linux virtual machine, allowing you to transfer documents and other files facilitating your work. To know more on how to use this feature keep reading!
creation.step7: When you are satisfied with your options, click on Confirm and Create

setup.step1: Select your newly created virtual machine from the menu on your left
setup.step1-1: Now you can start it using the button in the top right corner

before-we-start.note:
Due to a limitation imposed by Apple, you can create as many macOS VMs as you want, but you can only start two at any given time.
If you try to start more than two macOS virtual machines, you will be greeted by the following error.

creation.step2: Under Operating System, select macOS as the operating system of your choice
creation.step3-1: If you don't have a macOS .IPSW file yet, you can click on the left small button and choose your favourite to download.
creation.step4: Select the previously downloaded .IPSW recovery image
creation.step5-info: In case of custom parameters: macOS generally demands higher minimum requirements than Linux. To ensure an optimal experience, Tesseract will show warning if the parameters don't meet the minimum target.

setup.title: macOS Installation Process
setup.step2: Select Confirm when the alert dialog pops up
setup.step3: The installation process will start, don't worry if it takes time!
setup.step4: When the installation reaches 100%, the Virtual Machine shuts off automatically. Next time just start it and enjoy!

sidenote.message: Don't throw away your .IPSW files! Tesseract needs them to initialize your virtual machine at every startup. If the original file is deleted, or moved, the virtual machine will report a configuration error. Don't worry, you can always use another file: select your VM from the main menu and click on the installation media to select a new one.

before-we-start.title: Before we start
before-we-start.warning:
Most Linux distributions provide installation images for Intel processors, labeled with amd64.
These images are not compatible with Tesseract, because your mac has an Apple Silicon processor, that uses the arm64 architecture.
As long as it is compatible with arm64/aarch64 processors, you may use any Linux distribution!

creation.step2: Under Operating System, select Linux as the operating system of your choice
creation.step3-1: If you don't have a Linux .ISO file yet, you can click on the left small button and choose your favourite to download.
creation.step4: Select the previously downloaded .ISO image file
creation.step5-info:
In case of custom parameters: Depending on what kind of Linux environment you want, the minimum requirements may change drastically.
To make things simple for you, Tesseract's default values are tailored to give enough breathing room for most use cases.
Also, your physical mac will not slow down due to having an excessive amount of resources allocated to the VM

sidenote.message:
Every Linux distribution out there provides their own installer, unfortunately Tesseract cannot automate the process for you.
However, don't be scared to try and make mistakes, after all it's just a virtual machine, you can scrap it and start from scratch!
